bibl.title: Letter from James F. Waters to Philip Showalter Hench, October 2, 1941

div1.p: Waters sends Hench information on the recent "Court of Missing Heirs" program concerning Wallace Forbes, and inquires about another yellow fever volunteer.

div1.head: Letter from James F. Waters to Philip Showalter Hench, October 2, 1941
div1.opener:
The COURT of MISSING HEIRS
RADIO PROGRAM
572 Madison Avenue, New York
October 2, 1941
__________________________
JAMES F. WATERS · Authors · ALFRED SHEBEL
__________________________
Dr. P. S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
We were indeed interested in reading the contents
of your letter dated September 29th in reference to our recent
broadcast for Wallace Wellington Forbes.

The attached forms describe summary facts of our
broadcast and we shall be pleased to furnish any other information
that may assist friends of Mr. Forbes in their effort to locate
him.

The mother of Wallace Wellington Forbes is alive
today and living at Chicago, Illinois and we have several photo-
graphs of Mr. Forbes which we could make copies of should it be-
come of any value to you when contacting his friends.

We should like to know possibly if you recall
one of the men who submitted to Dr. Reed as having appeared on
“We The People” program some five or six months ago, since we
have received several letters indicating that fact but have not
as yet checked it with the program.

We shall be pleased to hear from you further
and let us know of such developments that may take place in
your communications with friends of Mr. Forbes.

Thanking you for your sincere interest in our
program, we remain
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, JAMES F. WATERS JFW/egh
Enc.
The Court of Missing Heirs is not vested with judicial power, and is not a court of law or a part of the judicial system of any
state. Rather it is a dramatization of facts broadcast from coast to coast in an effort to find the heirs to estates unknown to them.--
The sole purpose of this court is to render a public service gratuitously--to enable missing heirs to secure the legacies that are
rightfully theirs. It is not the purpose of the court to give legal advice--and it does not solicit or accept compensation from anyone.
